description.narrative: Establishing Parliament as a credible institution with greater role in policymaking and EU integration by: (a) improving effectiveness of Parliament; (b) strengthening policymaking and oversight functions; (c) enhancing its role in EU integration

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: Number of implemented IRP goals; Number of implemented OPG commitments; Evaluations by MPs of the work of IRD and PR Departments; MP induction system; Number of committee action plans and annual reports; Quality of committee conclusions on draft budget and budget execution reports; Quality of Parliament scrutiny of draft legislation, including for harmonized laws; Quality of explanatory notes accompanying the draft legislation; Integrated cross-committee action plan regarding AA/DCFTA; Number of citizens aware and supporting Georgia’s EU integration agenda.

comment.narrative: Despite achieved progress in parliamentary strengthening in recent years, the Georgian Parliament requires continued support, as there remain a number of areas that need to be addressed. In general terms, the Parliament is yet insufficiently strong vis-à-vis the Government, particularly visible through a low number of legislative initiatives by Members of Parliament and weak government oversight. Limited knowledge and skills of the Parliament staff result in insufficient services to the MPs. Consequently, technical expertise is frequently unavailable for MPs to scrutinize legislation and initiate draft laws. Budgetary and financial scrutiny by sector committees requires further strengthening. Although Parliament succeeded in developing a number of strategic documents, like IRP and OPG AP, both need to be followed up and operationalized. The Parliament is also faced with the challenge of increasing its role in the European integration process through adequate involvement in the legal harmonization exercise and effective government scrutiny of the AA/DCFTA implementation. MPs and staff lack sufficient knowledge of European issues, which also results in low public awareness on Georgia-EU relations.

Institutional Reform Plan (IRP) review is conducted, recommendations drafted and the IRP is updated for the next two years (209-2020). Organizational Development Plan/Strategy is prepared for the newly-established Research Service of the Parliament. Selected commitments under the 2018-2019 Open Parliament Action Plan are implemented. Parliamentary committees reporting capacities (reporting against their multi-year action plans) are improved through development of the Monitoring and Evaluation Methodology, committee staff training and on-the-jbo consultancy (two pilot committees produce their first results-based reports). Committee Staff Manual is developed (adjusted) to comply with the new Rules of Procedure of the Parliament. Parliament staff capacities in EU legal approximation are further increased through provision of practical trainings and on-the-job-consultancy.

Progress of the Institutional Reform Plan (IRP) implementation was conducted revealing 16 out of 20 strategic goals having been completed; remaining gaps and challenges were identified and the new IRP was elaborated for 2019-2020, pending approval by the Parliament Bureau. Organizational Development Plan/Strategy of the Parliamentary Research Centre has not been yet prepared due to the delays in the official establishment of the Centre and follow-up recruitments of the Centre staff (Centre will be fully staffed by mid-January 2020). The development of the Centre’s strategy and action plan is envisaged within the new UNDP project “Consolidating Parliamentary Democracy in Georgia”. Selected commitments under the 2018-2019 Open Parliament Action Plan have been implemented, including development and adoption of the Parliament’s strategy and action plan for the implementation and monitoring of the SDGs, elaboration of the Communications Strategy for the Parliament’s Open Governance Council and Social Media Concept for the Parliament. Parliamentary committees reporting capacities have been improved through development of the Monitoring and Evaluation Methodology – a total of 10 committees engaged in the exercise and produced their M&E plans and three of them produced their quarterly reports in a new – results-based – format. Committee Staff Manual has been developed to be in line with the new Rules of Procedure of the Parliament. Parliament staff capacities in EU legal approximation have been further increased through provision of practical trainings and technical expertise on a number of draft laws. The Parliament’s Action Plan for the implementation and oversight of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement has been approved by the Parliament Bureau. An awareness raising campaign has been conducted on the new parliamentary procedures targeting different groups, including CSOs, media and youth as well as a general public.
Final Results against the Indicators - 80% of strategic goals and objectives of the IRP have been implemented. 95% of Open Parliament Action Plans (2015-2016; 2017) have been implemented (implementation of 2018-2019 Action Plan stands at 32% in view of the delays in launching the Parliament’s new website and also – due to the political tensions starting from June 2019). MPs positively assess the performance of the new Inter-Parliamentary Unit under the International Relations Department with recommendations for improvement (e.g. to provide less general information in the briefer and be more specific on parliamentary relations). A total of 6 parliamentary committees drafted their multi-year action plans with the project support, although with the parliament’s decision to institutionalize the process through the new Rules of Procedure, as of February 2019 – all committees have drafted their annual plans and shall continue so on annual basis. 10 committees elaborated their M&E plans and three of them reported against the new plans. Quality of committee conclusions on draft budget and budget execution reports have been promoted through the delivery of targeted trainings and on-the-job-consultancies. Although due to the limited interest from the committees, only 2 of them – Environmental Protection and Sports and Youth Affairs committees – engaged intensively and demonstrated their raised capacities through elaboration of quality conclusions on the draft budget, attracting additional funds to their respective spheres. Parliament’s capacities in law drafting/legal approximation has been improved through capacity development trainings for the staff and provision of technical expertise, as a result of which - Committee on European Integration presented its substantive conclusions on 5 pieces of legislation, initiated a law on Consumer Protection, and co-drafted a Law on Tourism. Adoption of the amendments on the new structure and contents of the explanatory notes and the development of the respective guidelines shall further improve the quality of explanatory notes accompanying the draft legislation. The Parliament’s action plan for the implementation and oversight of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement was developed and approved by the Parliament Bureau. Awareness raising campaigns on the EU integration and specifically the Parliament’s role in the process targeted 1000 students from 9 universities in Tbilisi and regions and 400 school children from 45 public schools of Kutaisi, Gori and Rustavi; social media campaign reached at least 4,000 people.
